channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.
channel.dc:rights: © 2022 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Sieving in order
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01351-w

Designing highly ordered and ultrathin nanoporous membranes achieves superior water flux, while maintaining high selectivity for NaCl rejection.
item.dc:title: Sieving in order
item.dc:creator: Chrystelle Salameh
Damien Voiry

item.title: Neighbours in charge
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01366-3

Resonant X-ray scattering experiments have revealed a charge-ordered phase next to the recently discovered superconducting phase in layered nickelates — in remarkable analogy to the cuprate high-temperature superconductors.
item.dc:title: Neighbours in charge
item.dc:creator: Eva Benckiser
Matthias Hepting
Bernhard Keimer

item.title: Steering from the rear
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01357-4

In the absence of biochemical gradients, cancer cell migration over fibrillar isotropic collagen can occur by a mechanical self-steering process involving asymmetric matrix deformation from the rear.
item.dc:title: Steering from the rear
item.dc:creator: Katarina Wolf
Peter Friedl

item.title: Innovation for green
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01371-6

Gang Qian from CITIC Pacific Special Steel, one of the major steelmakers in China, talks to Nature Materials about their experience and perspective on moving towards decarbonization.
item.dc:title: Innovation for green
item.dc:creator: Xin Li

item.title: Striving for green steel
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01379-y

Steel underpins modern society but its production generates intensive carbon dioxide emissions. For its sustainable development, the steel industry requires technology and product upgrades, driven by innovation and cooperation.
item.dc:title: Striving for green steel

item.title: A fridge without a cause
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01377-0

A fridge without a cause
item.dc:title: A fridge without a cause
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: Carbon neutrality orientates the reform of the steel industry
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 23 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01370-7

The steel industry in China has an important role in reducing national and global carbon emissions, demanding integrated actions and efforts across policies, industry and science to achieve the goal of carbon neutrality.
item.dc:title: Carbon neutrality orientates the reform of the steel industry
item.dc:creator: Zhuo Kang
Qingliang Liao
Zheng Zhang
Yue Zhang

item.title: Giant magnon spin conductivity in ultrathin yttrium iron garnet films
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 22 September 2022; doi:10.1038/s41563-022-01369-0

The authors report the observation of an enhanced magnon conductivity close to the two-dimensional transport regime in ultrathin yttrium iron garnet.
item.dc:title: Giant magnon spin conductivity in ultrathin yttrium iron garnet films
item.dc:creator: X.-Y. Wei
O. Alves Santos
C. H. Sumba Lusero
G. E. W. Bauer
J. Ben Youssef
B. J. van Wees
